fields.summary: Cloud Administrator Can't Control ELB, AS, Cloudwatch Resources of non-eucalyptus account Users

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
{panel:title=Assessment|borderStyle=dashed|borderColor=#000000|titleBGColor=#CCCC99|bgColor=#CCCCCC}
In the [Eucalyptus Administration Guide|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#shared/manage_section.html], there isn't any section that discusses how Cloud Administrators can manage resources of non-eucalyptus accounts.  This is important so that Cloud Administrators can have a sense of how much control they have for managing cloud resources of users.

Under this section, the following information should be covered:
* Managing EC2 resources (i.e. instances, volumes, keypairs, security groups, etc.) 
* Managing Walrus (S3) resources (i.e. buckets and objects)
* Managing CloudWatch resources
* Managing ELB resources
* Managing AutoScaling resources
* Managing IAM resources

For the most part, "managing" here means displaying and deleting resources.  There are a few cases where modifying resources is needed.
{panel}
{panel:title=Pertinent Data|borderStyle=dashed|borderColor=#000000|titleBGColor=#CCCC99|bgColor=#CCCCCC}
This ticket is driven by the information in the following tickets:
* EUCA-7994
* EUCA-8074
* EUCA-8076
* DOC-639
{panel}
{panel:title=Suggestion for Documentation|borderStyle=dashed|borderColor=#000000|titleBGColor=#CCCC99|bgColor=#CCCCCC}
Below is a suggestion of what could be used to document this information. I recommend we sync with the QA team to make sure all situations are covered.  
----

h2.  Managing Cloud Resources

The focus of this section is to cover how cloud administrators can manage cloud resources for accounts, excluding [the special identity account *eucalyptus*|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#admin-guide/access_special_ids.html].  The following resources can be managed by the cloud administrator:
\\
\\
* EC2 Resources
* Walrus (S3) Resources
* Euare (IAM) Resources
* CloudWatch Resources
* ELB Resources
* AutoScaling Resources

h4.  EC2 Resources

To view all the EC2 resources on a Eucalyptus cloud, just pass the keyword _verbose_ to any euca-describe-* command.  For example, 
* {code}
euca-describe-instances verbose
{code}
* {code}
euca-describe-volumes verbose
{code}
* {code}
euca-describe-keypairs verbose
{code}

Any resource that is displayed can be deleted/removed by using the appropriate euca-delete-* command ^\[1\]^. For additional information regarding the euca-describe-* commands available, please refer to the section [_EC2-Compatible Commands_ in the Euca2ools Guide|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euca.html].  

h4.  Walrus (S3) Resources

_Not really sure what goes here, but I am thinking whatever information we put in DOC-818, but with a focus from more of the cloud administrator point-of-view._

h4.  Euare (IAM) Resources

With Euare (IAM) resources, there is the ability to describe, add, delete, or modify policies, users and groups.  For all euare commands that describe, add, delete, or modify resources, there is the option to use _--as-account_.  This way, the cloud administrator can assume the role of the admin user of a given account. Some examples are as follows:
* {code}
euare-grouplistbypath --as-account foo
{code}
* {code}
euare-userlistbypath --as-account bar
{code}
* {code}
euare-userdelloginprofile --as-account foo -u acme
{code}
* {code}
euare-usermod --as-account foo -u acme -n acmefoo
{code}

For additional information regarding Euare commands, please refer to the section [_IAM-Compatible Commands_ in the Euca2ools Guide|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/eiam.html].

h4.  CloudWatch Resources

For CloudWatch resources, cloud administrators can list, delete, modify and set cloudwatch resources for the cloud ^\[3\]^ .  

To list (i.e. describe) cloudwatch alarms for the cloud, execute the following command:
* {code}
euwatch-describe-alarms verbose
{code}

The following commands support being controlled administratively when the cloudwatch resource ARN is used.  To discover the cloudwatch resource ARN, use _euwatch-describe-alarms_ with the _--show-long_ option with the keyword _verbose_:
\\
\\
* [euwatch-delete-alarms|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch-delete-alarms.html]
* [euwatch-disable-alarm-actions|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch-disable-alarm-actions.html]
* [euwatch-describe-alarm-history|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch-describe-alarm-history.html]
* [euwatch-enable-alarm-actions|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch-enable-alarm-actions.html]
* [euwatch-set-alarm-state|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch-set-alarm-state.html]
* [euwatch-describe-alarms-for-metric|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch-describe-alarms-for-metric.html]

For additional information regarding euwatch commands, please refer to the section [_CloudWatch-Compatible Commands_ in the Euca2ools Guide|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euwatch.html].

h4.  ELB Resources

For ELB resources, there is the ability to list and delete.  In order to list (i.e. describe) all the ELB resources of a cloud, with any eulb-describe-* command, pass the keyword _verbose_ .  Here are a couple of examples:
* {code}
eulb-describe-lb-policies verbose
{code}
* {code}
eulb-describe-lb-policy-types verbose
{code}
* {code}
eulb-describe-lbs verbose
{code}

To delete any load balancer or any load balancer resource on the cloud,  instead of using the ELB name, use the DNS name.  For example:
* {code}
## describe the ELB
$ eulb-describe-lbs verbose
LOAD_BALANCER	MyLoadBalancer	MyLoadBalancer-961915002812.lb.foobar.eucalyptus-systems.com	2013-10-30T03:02:53.39Z

## Delete the ELB
$ eulb-delete-lb MyLoadBalancer-961915002812.lb.foobar.eucalyptus-systems.com 
$ eulb-describe-lbs verbose 
$
{code}

For additional information regarding the ELB commands, please refer to the section [_Elastic Load Balancing Commands_ in the Euca2ools Guide|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/eulb.html].

h4.  AutoScaling Resources

Cloud Administrators can list, delete, update and suspend cloud Autoscaling Resources ^\[2\]^.   To list (e.g. describe) autoscaling resources for the cloud, pass the flag _--show-long_ with the keyword _verbose_  with any euscale-describe-* command.  For example:
* {code}
euscale-describe-launch-configs --show-long verbose
{code}
* {code}
euscale-describe-auto-scaling-groups --show-long verbose
{code}

The following euscale-describe-* commands support the keyword _verbose_:
\\
\\
* [euscale-describe-auto-scaling-groups|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-describe-auto-scaling-groups.html]
* [euscale-describe-auto-scaling-instances|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-describe-auto-scaling-instances.html]
* [euscale-describe-launch-configs|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-describe-launch-configs.html]
* [euscale-describe-policies|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-describe-policies.html]
* [euscale-describe-scaling-activities|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-describe-scaling-activities.html]

For deleting resources, the ARN of the resource must be used.  For example:
* {code}
## Describe launch configs to get ARN using --show-long and verbose
$ euscale-describe-launch-configs --show-long verbose
LAUNCH-CONFIG	TestLaunchConfig	emi-06663A57	m1.medium						2013-10-30T22:52:39.392Z	true	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:launchConfiguration:5ac29caf-9aad-4bdb-b228-5fce841dc062:launchConfigurationName/TestLaunchConfig

## Deleting resource using ARN
$ euscale-delete-launch-config
arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:launchConfiguration:5ac29caf-9aad-4bdb-b228-5fce841dc062:launchConfigurationName/TestLaunchConfig
{code}

The following euscale-delete-* commands can be used for cloud administrative control:
\\
\\
* [euscale-delete-auto-scaling-group|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-delete-auto-scaling-group.html]
* [euscale-delete-launch-configuration|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-delete-launch-configuration.html]
* [euscale-delete-policy|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-delete-policy.html]

For updating cloud autoscaling resources, just like when autoscaling resources are deleted, the ARN is needed.  The following euscale commands can be used for administratively updating resources:
\\
\\
* [euscale-disable-metrics-collection|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-disable-metrics-collection.html]
* [euscale-enable-metrics-collection|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-enable-metrics-collection.html]
* [euscale-execute-policy|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-execute-policy.html]
* [euscale-resume-processes|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-resume-processes.html]
* [euscale-set-desired-capacity|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-set-desired-capacity.html]
* [euscale-suspend-processes|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-suspend-processes.html]
* [euscale-terminate-instance-in-auto-scaling-group|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-terminate-instance-in-auto-scaling-group.html]
* [euscale-update-auto-scaling-group|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale-update-auto-scaling-group.html]

For additional information about these and other euscale commands, please refer to the section [_AutoScaling-Compatible Commands_ in the Euca2ools Guide|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euscale.html].


----
^\[1\]^ not sure about [euca-revoke|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euca-revoke.html], [euca-release-address|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euca-release-address.html], [euca-disassociate-address|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euca-disassociate-address.html], [euca-cancel-bundle-task|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euca-cancel-bundle-task.html] or [euca-unmonitor-instances|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#euca2ools-guide/euca-unmonitor-instances.html]
^\[2\]^ https://github.com/eucalyptus/architecture/wiki/autoscaling-3.3-design#wiki-Administrative_Functionality
^\[3\]^ https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-8074?focusedCommentId=57871&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-57871
{panel}
fields.summary: Section Discussing How Cloud Administrators Can Control Cloud Users Resources is Missing

comments.body:
[~hspencer], Management is two-fold: static system-wide limits, set as configurable properties and only accessible by the cloud administrator, and per-account/user limits configurable by account admins via IAM policies.

Configurable properties:
* walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb -- maximum size of any given bucket, default is 5*1024 -- 5GB. The eucalyptus/admin is not subject to this limit

* walrus.storagemaxbucketsperaccount -- maximum number of buckets for a single account. Default is 100. Again, eucalyptus/admin is exempt.

* walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb -- for the walrus image cache. This also limits the maximum sized image allowed to run in the system. Cache is a mis-nomer, it should be 'workspace'. Default is 30GB.

* walrus.storagemaxtotalcapacity -- This is a calculated number based on disk size available for walrus. It is used *ONLY* for reporting usage (e.g 80% used) and does not impose any limits. It is worth noting that a reporting number >100% is possible if capacity is added without adjusting this value.

* walrus.storagemaxtotalsnapshotsizeingb -- upper limit of total cumulative size of all snapshots in the system. Default is 50GB

The IAM quotas, that can be applied by account administrators, use the IAM condition keys:
* "s3:quota-bucketnumber" - integer
* "s3:quota-buckettotalsize" - in mb
* "s3:quota-bucketsize" - in mb
* "s3:quota-bucketobjectnumber" - integer

These can be used like this, for example to limit the users allowed bucket size.
{code}
"Condition": {
  "NumericLessThan" : {
     "s3:quota-bucketsize" : "10000"
     ... (you can have any or all of the conditions here)
   }
}
{code}

NOTE: I haven't tested all of the iam conditions myself but they haven't changed since 3.0. Application of user limits is a bit strange in S3 because S3 doesn't really work on 'users', but rather accounts, so per-user quotas are a bit strange.

[~zhill],

Thanks for the information man.  This is really helpful.  Question though, if you are a cloud administrator (i.e. a user under the eucalyptus account), can you "override" bucket ACLs created by users from a non-eucalyptus account (what I mean by override here is that can cloud administrators access objects, modify bucket ACLs that were created by users from non-eucalyptus accounts)?  

Thanks again for your help with this.

Sure, [~hspencer]. No problem.

To answer your question: yes, the eucalyptus/admin user overrides all the normal IAM and ACL checks in Walrus (or at least should, if we find cases where that is not the case it is a bug). However, be aware that the "ListAllMyBuckets" operation (GET / on the service, or 's3 cmd ls') executed by the eucalyptus account will list only buckets owned by that account, even though it has access to all of them. So the trick is to know the bucket name.

[~tony], yes.  For example, if account _foo_ has ACLs on a bucket for READ only for account _bar_, can a user from the _eucalyptus_ account still read/write to that bucket?  Based upon [~zhill]'s answer, this is a yes, but the cloud admin needs to know the bucket name.  Has this been your experience?
Hi - good stuff. Question how does one list all buckets of all users/accounts?

At the moment there is no single command to get all buckets in the system. The only way would be for the eucalyptus admin to get all the accounts and their credentials and then spoof each one and execute a 'list buckets' (GET / on the service) operation. Buckets and objects are owned by accounts, never users, so an enumeration of accounts would be sufficient. This is a limitation of the S3 API itself.
[~hspencer], you have one euwatch- command that takes the verbose option, and the others take a show-long option. Shouldn't they all just use --show-long?

Hey [~smarvin],

For all the euwatch-describe-* commands, the _verbose_ option provides the high-level details.  However if a cloud administrator wants to see more details information, the _--show-long_ option provides that.  [~ethomas], is this true for all the eucawatch-describe-* commands?

Example below:
{code}
$ euwatch-describe-alarms verbose --region admin@
TestAddCapacity	INSUFFICIENT_DATA	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:scalingPolicy:2d9fe100-1d42-4627-8249-6f83f34805db:autoScalingGroupName/TestScalingGroup:policyName/TestScaleoutPolicy	AWS/EC2	CPUUtilization	120	Average	2	GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold	80.0
RemoveCapacity	INSUFFICIENT_DATA	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:scalingPolicy:3dd5b095-023f-41be-a52e-1e6f537632a9:autoScalingGroupName/TestScalingGroup:policyName/TestScaleinPolicy	AWS/EC2	CPUUtilization	120	Average	2	LessThanOrEqualToThreshold	40.0


$ euwatch-describe-alarms verbose --show-long --region admin@
TestAddCapacity		INSUFFICIENT_DATA	Insufficient Data: 2 datapoints were unknown.	{"version":"1.0","queryDate":"2013-11-04T23:35:42.852+0000","statistic":"Average","recentDatapoints":[],"period":120,"threshold":80}	true		arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:scalingPolicy:2d9fe100-1d42-4627-8249-6f83f34805db:autoScalingGroupName/TestScalingGroup:policyName/TestScaleoutPolicy		AWS/EC2	CPUUtilization	{AutoScalingGroupName=TestScalingGroup}	120	Average	Percent	2	GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold	80.0
RemoveCapacity		INSUFFICIENT_DATA	Insufficient Data: 2 datapoints were unknown.	{"version":"1.0","queryDate":"2013-11-04T23:35:42.854+0000","statistic":"Average","recentDatapoints":[],"period":120,"threshold":40}	true		arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:scalingPolicy:3dd5b095-023f-41be-a52e-1e6f537632a9:autoScalingGroupName/TestScalingGroup:policyName/TestScaleinPolicy		AWS/EC2	CPUUtilization	{AutoScalingGroupName=TestScalingGroup}	120	Average	Percent	2	LessThanOrEqualToThreshold	40.0
{code}

Hope this helps.  Let me know if there are additional questions.
[~hspencer], does this hold true (that is, the verbose vs. --show-long) for all commands? Because some other examples you used have one or the other.

[~smarvin],

From what I have seen - yes.  For example,
* using _verbose_ only
{code}
$ euscale-describe-launch-configs verbose --region admin@
LAUNCH-CONFIG	TestLaunchConfig	emi-06663A57	m1.medium
LAUNCH-CONFIG	JenkinsSwarmDemo	emi-2A773CF3	m1.medium
LAUNCH-CONFIG	AS-Test	emi-4EFE3A91	m1.medium
{code}
* using _verbose_ and _--show-long_
{code}
$ euscale-describe-launch-configs --show-long verbose --region admin@
LAUNCH-CONFIG	TestLaunchConfig	emi-06663A57	m1.medium						2013-10-30T15:52:39.392Z	true	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:launchConfiguration:5ac29caf-9aad-4bdb-b228-5fce841dc062:launchConfigurationName/TestLaunchConfi
LAUNCH-CONFIG	JenkinsSwarmDemo	emi-2A773CF3	m1.medium	euca-admin					2013-07-24T11:59:08.927Z	true	arn:aws:autoscaling::441445882805:launchConfiguration:14db98aa-3dc3-4f55-aa5a-8d6e06f4ed75:launchConfigurationName/JenkinsSwarmDemo
LAUNCH-CONFIG	AS-Test	emi-4EFE3A91	m1.medium						2014-01-24T20:38:56.197Z	true	arn:aws:autoscaling::961915002812:launchConfiguration:84703b46-34b1-4f73-a5d0-a2156274ec8c:launchConfigurationName/AS-Test
{code}

So in short, from a cloud administrator point-of-view, using _verbose_ with any describe resource command will show you the resources used on the entire cloud.  With the euca2ools commands for specifically AutoScale (euscale-describe-*), Cloudwatch (euwatch-describe-*), and ELB (eulb-describe-*), the _--show-long_ provides additional information.  

Hope this helps.  Let me know if you need additional information.

Thanks, [~hspencer]. That helps. 

I don't have any information about Walrus so that might not make it in for 3.4.2, unless you can clear up more about what you're looking for in DOC-818 (I find that whole thread pretty confusing--plus, we haven't opened the S3-compatible API up in Euca2ools, as far as I know).

[~smarvin],

Regarding Walrus information, I think we can take the information provided in [the comment from Zach above|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/DOC-1125?focusedCommentId=59537&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-59537], and use the [information in DOC-818|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/DOC-818?focusedCommentId=57127&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-57127] to cover cloud administrator management of resources.

Does that help out?
[~hspencer], can you review the new section of the admin guide, starting on page 59? It's mainly your suggestions. However, I don't have any information for IAM yet.

[~smarvin],

Looking at the section regarding "Manage Walrus Resources", I suggest the following:

* Adding links to the following AWS resources:
** Bucket ACLs
*** http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ACLOverview.html
*** http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ACLUsingRESTAPI.html
** IAM Policies
*** http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingIAMPolicies.html
* Based upon the current content, I would mention that we don't support 'Bucket Policies' ([~zhill], mind chiming in here to make sure I am correct about this for 3.4.2).  So for example, add the following changes:
----
*Bucket Policies:* These are IAM-like policies set by the bucket owner that allow the owner to specify access controls for other users or accounts for that specific bucket. A bucket policy looks like an IAM policy, but the policy is uploaded to S3, not IAM, and the bucket owner sets it rather than the account admin. A bucket policy can allow or deny access to accounts and IAM users in multiple accounts by the bucket owners. Any ACL can be translated into bucket policy, but not the other way around.  {color:red}*This is NOT supported in versions of Eucalyptus 3.4.x, and earlier*.{color}
----

Hope this helps.  Let me know if there are any questions.
All comments in Admin Guide now.
